clinical_study.brief_title: Faith-based Approaches in the Treatment of Hypertension (FAITH)
clinical_study.official_title: Faith-based Approaches in the Treatment of Hypertension (FAITH)

lead_sponsor.agency: New York University School of Medicine

collaborator.agency: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

clinical_study.source: New York University School of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to test the effect of a church-based lifestyle intervention on blood pressure reduction in 400 hypertensive blacks (BP> 140/90 mm hg).

detailed_description.textblock: This study will test the effectiveness of a church-based lifestyle intervention in improving blood pressure control among 400 hypertensive blacks in a group randomized controlled trial. The lifestyle intervention will be delivered by trained lay health advisers through group-based behavioral counseling and motivational interviewing (MINT-TLC) in 24 predominantly black churches in New York City.

primary_outcome.measure: Within-individual change in systolic blood pressure and diastolic blood pressure

secondary_outcome.measure: Dietary intake of fruits and vegetables

arm_group.description: This MINT-TLC group will be asked to attend 12 weekly counseling meetings focused on weight loss (if overweight), limiting sodium, regular physical activity, and eating a low-fat diet that is rich in fruit and vegetables. MINT-TLC will be conducted by trained Lay Health Advisors. Participants will attend weekly group classes targeted at lifestyle changes for the first 12 weeks (intensive phase); followed by three individual MINT sessions conducted monthly for the following three months (maintenance phase). The MINT-TLC sessions aim to help participants make useful therapeutic lifestyle changes (TLC) and develop skills to maintain these changes long-term.

Participants randomized to this control condition will receive traditional, group health education classes for 12 weeks delivered by experts on various health topics unrelated to hypertension such as cancer, health insurance, and depression.

intervention.description: The MINT-TLC lifestyle intervention lead by lay health advisers will be compared to the health education attention control condition (CC). Twenty churches will participate in the study and each church will be randomly assigned to receive either MINT-TLC or CC. They will be compared on blood pressure reduction, physical activity levels, intake of fruits and vegetables, and weight reduction.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 18 years or older
- Diagnosis of hypertension
- Self-identified Black or African American
- SBP > 140 mmHg or DBP > 90 mmHg (based on the average of 3 blood pressure readings); or average SBP > 130 mm Hg or DBP > 80 mm hg (for those with diabetes or kidney disease) at the screening/baseline visits
- Able to speak English
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unable to comply with the study protocol (either self-selected or by indicating during screening that s/he could not complete all requested tasks).
- Pregnancy
